executive_summary: The printing industry is experiencing a steady decline as digital products and services displace printed materials. The largest markets, advertising and publishing, have shifted online, reducing printing demand. Corporate profit declines and higher interest rates have caused advertising expenditure to plummet. Other products like retail catalogs and banking forms have also seen low demand due to e-commerce and online financial transactions. These trends have caused revenue to fall at a CAGR of 1.1% to an estimated $90.3 billion over the past five years, including an estimated 3.0% slump in 2024. Higher input costs and the shift to digital have also harmed profit for printing services.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Newspaper and magazine subscriptions, an important indicator of printing demand, have fallen due to the rise of digital media. Advertisers have shifted spending to digital marketing and away from print materials like mailers and catalogs produced by printers. Many companies view digital marketing as more environmentally friendly and measurable.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Modernization results in falling commercial demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Retailers have demanded fewer print catalogs as more sales and browsing happen online. The rise of digital has drastically reduced demand for some printed packaging used at retail, like shopping bags.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Digitization will continue to threaten industry growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Digital media's growth will hurt print periodical circulation and advertising. Book publishers will seek shorter print runs due to technology advancements. E-books will continue gaining popularity due to low prices and accessibility.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Specialized and niche needs will sustain printers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Print remains important for some marketing campaigns. Direct mail is appealing for reaching broad audiences. As publications struggle, more will outsource printing to cut costs. Improved digital printing enables shorter, customized runs.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The structure of the industry will continue to evolve
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Many printers will transition to cross-media products like multimedia layout and design. AI will impact internal workflows. Alternative technologies like the internet will dampen demand for traditional printing.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The new generation will bring hope to the industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Generation Z seeks disconnection from digital screens, creating niche demand for print books and advertising. Over two-thirds of young adults between 18-29 consume physical books.

industry_definition: Companies in the Printing industry primarily print on paper, textile products, metal, glass, plastic and other materials, excluding fabric. Manufacturers engage in various printing processes including lithographic, gravure, screen, flexographic, digital and letterpress processes. This industry doesn't include publishers that also perform printing, nor does it comprise companies that perform prepress or post-press services without traditional printing.
key_trends: Digital primacy is now the norm, with the printing industry losing ground to digital publications.
Commercial gravure printing is declining due to high costs and slow speed compared to offset printing.
Printing services continue to face notable and consistent declines over several decades due to increasing digital alternatives.
Advancements in communication erode demand for printing services, though specialized needs and younger demographics' preferences might sustain niches.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Manufacturers use printing services primarily to produce labels on consumer goods like food and health products. Flexographic printing is the most common form of label production, followed by screen printing, lithography, gravure and letterpress.

Advertising includes direct mail, inserts, catalogs, directories and screen-printed signs. Major customers in this market include retailers, wholesalers, household services firms and business services firms.
Some book, magazine and periodical publishers use printing services to print their content. Magazines and periodicals make up most of this segment.
Financial and legal firms often use forms printed by this industry. Banks, for example, demand printing services to produce checkbooks and deposit slips.

products_and_services.product_description: Lithographic printing remains an essential service for printers. This method leverages economies of scale, making it ideal for commercial printers to effectively serve larger businesses and manufacturers via large-run contracts.
Flexographic printing, mainly used for labels and wrappers, involves a rotary process that prints from rubber or flexible plates and uses fast-drying inks.

In the screen-printing process, ink is transferred to an object through a mesh screen containing a stencil of the desired final image. This method is primarily useful for printing materials other than paper, like textiles, product labels, posters or decals.
Digital printing has expanded significantly. Digital printing does not require printing plates, making it more cost-effective for small print runs since there is less initial setup involved.

The industry prints a range of other miscellaneous products. These products include loose-leaf binders, checkbooks and business forms, and historically significant printing methods that have fallen out of favor, like letterpress and engraving.
Book printing involves printing and binding books and pamphlets. Typically, book printers bind the books as well; printers are not responsible for publishing books.
Gravure printing is a rotary process in which the image is etched into a metal plate attached to a cylinder. The cylinder is rotated through a trough of ink.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Print advertising expenditure includes spending on advertising in magazines and newspapers. When advertising expenditure decreases, newspapers and magazines reduce their output of pages and consolidate operations, posing a potential threat to printing servicers.

Magazine, newspaper, database and book publishers are among the primary consumers of printing services. When publishing industries thrive, the printing industry usually experiences a significant revenue gain.

Manufacturers represent the largest market for printing services. When manufacturing capacity utilization rises, manufacturers produce more consumer goods, increasing their demand for industry packaging products.
Paper is one of the primary inputs used by the printing industry; consequently, the cost of paper affects demand for printed material. Higher paper prices generally raise revenue.

international_trade_points.trade_title: China continues to be a core import destination
international_trade_points.trade_description: China is the primary source of imports in the global printing industry, benefiting from lower wages and reduced input costs.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Imports will remain low in the near future
international_trade_points.trade_description: Heightened tensions with China will continue to hinder import penetration from overseas. However, falling demand amid a shift to paperless communication will keep China's share of imports stable.

international_trade_points.trade_title: US exports to a handful of foreign markets
international_trade_points.trade_description: US export revenue is down, with Canada, Mexico, the UK, and China now the top foreign destinations. China has overtaken Germany as the fourth-largest export market.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Exports will fall following digitization trends
international_trade_points.trade_description: Export revenue is set to fall as rising internet use curbs demand for printed materials overseas. The trend mirrors domestic market shifts.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast has the largest concentration of business establishments in the printing industry due to the region's dense population, which drives demand for printing services from businesses across various sectors.

The Mid-Atlantic region hosts a substantial share of printing servicers due to its major metropolitan areas, which boost demand across various consumer niches. This region boasts a higher number of book printers, attributed to the significant concentration of book publishers.

The manufacturing industry significantly benefits the Great Lakes region, with several states such as Illinois, Wisconsin and Minnesota having a higher share of employment compared with overall establishment counts. Printing services in this area often operate on a larger scale, likely due to the strong presence of the manufacturing sector.

regulations_points.regulation_description: US Patent and Trademark Laws play a critical role in safeguarding intellectual property rights among printing services. Patent or trademark infringement can lead to substantial financial penalties, encouraging compliance among printing manufacturers.
The Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, also known as the Financial Services Modernization Act of 1999, mandates that companies handling sensitive information, such as bank checks, secure this data.

The Clean Air Act (CAA) regulates all sources of air emissions in the U.S. It authorizes the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to set National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS) to safeguard public health and the environment.

The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) sets and enforces workplace safety standards for printing services. These regulations cover areas like chemical handling, machine guarding, and respiratory protection.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The printing industry is in the decline stage of its life cycle.

basis_points.basis_title: Digital primacy is now the norm
basis_points.basis_description: Digital primacy is now the norm, with the printing industry losing ground to digital publications.

Commercial gravure printing is declining. The high costs and slow speed associated with this method, coupled with high inflationary pressures, made offset printing the preferred choice for customers due to its quicker turnaround and cost-efficiency.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The Printing industry is highly fragmented, with no printing company accounting for a significant market share. Commercial printers in the United States are typically privately owned and generate less than $2.0 million in annual sales on average.
The number of businesses will continue to drop due to consolidation and more underperforming printing presses exiting the market.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases account for the highest share of revenue
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs continue to make up the largest expenditure for printing services due to the high quantity of raw materials necessary for printing. Some of the most common purchase costs include paper, ink, film, offset plates, chemicals and cartons.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: The cost of paper has significantly increased in recent years
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The cost of paper has significantly increased in recent years, as heightened inflation has boosted many core expenditures for printing services.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The slow adoption of production automation among smaller printers results in high labor costs. Printing servicers are in constant need of qualified and skilled employees, boosting training requirements and expanding labor costs across the industry.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Steady digitization growth exacerbates printing services volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Print-based advertising has steadily decreased, resulting in consistent but gradual revenue loss. This has caused a consistent level of revenue volatility, as more technological adoption continues to change how information proliferates.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Volatile economic conditions significantly affect consumer habits
volatility_points.volatility_description: Printing services are highly susceptible to shifts in economic conditions. During periods of economic instability, consumers tend to seek cost-efficient alternatives, reducing demand for printed products.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: LIMITED INNOVATION ACROSS PRINTING SERVICES LANDSCAPE
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The printing industry struggles with limited product innovation. Technological advancements are slow, affecting changes to existing offerings and hampering overall growth and development.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: The industry responds to trends in print advertising spending but has been in a state of structural decline driven by new technology.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Many printers have expanded into ancillary creative services as demand for printed material has declined.

FAQs.question: Has your company located in proximity to its key downstream distributors to reduce shipping costs?
FAQs.answer: In certain segments, such as packaging printing, industry companies benefit by being close to manufacturing markets.

FAQs.question: Printing products undergo little technical change, but industry companies have generally expanded their digital printing capabilities.
FAQs.answer: Printing products undergo little technical change, but industry companies have generally expanded their digital printing capabilities.

FAQs.question: Digital printing methods have reduced setup time and reduced labor costs.
FAQs.answer: Digital printing methods have reduced setup time and reduced labor costs.

FAQs.question: The industry's employees aren't exposed to significant occupational hazards.
FAQs.answer: The industry's employees aren't exposed to significant occupational hazards.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations such as energy-efficiency standards?
FAQs.answer: The industry will not face substantial environmental regulation, but environmentally friendly printing methods may attract customers.

FAQs.question: What challenges does your company face financing its ongoing operations?
FAQs.answer: The industry is operating with excess capacity, which depresses prices and makes it difficult for printers to cover fixed costs.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Capital costs are relatively high in the industry because printers regularly invest in new equipment.

FAQs.question: Does your company rely on skilled labor? What skills must your employees have?
FAQs.answer: Given the serious shortage of skilled tradespeople in the printing industry, firms that can ensure an adequate labor supply have a distinct market advantage.

FAQs.question: Does your company keep pace with technological advancements? Does your company have access to the latest print technology?
FAQs.answer: New technology can improve efficiency, reduce labor costs and improve product quality. Firms that maximize their utilization of state-of-the-art technologies enhance their competitiveness.

FAQs.question: How important is marketing expertise for the successful operations of your company? How much of your revenue is spent on marketing?
FAQs.answer: Given a high level of competition, marketing expertise can be important. In small print-run markets, where it can be important to develop relationships with local business, franchise systems have developed.

FAQs.question: How much has your company been affected by the decline in print advertising expenditure? What other income streams have you explored?
FAQs.answer: Print advertising expenditure includes spending on advertising in magazines and newspapers.

FAQs.question: How has your company contended with waning demand from publishing industries? Have you made changes to your product mix?
FAQs.answer: Magazine, newspaper, database and book publishers are among the primary users of printing services.

FAQs.question: Does your company monitor the level of manufacturing capacity utilization? How does this affect your revenue?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers represent the largest market for industry products. Manufacturing facilities that operate around the clock benefit from continuous use, as capacity utilization is maximized.
